titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Leon F. Litwack Collection of Berkeley, California, Protest Literature
Litwack (Leon F.) Collection of Berkeley, California, Protest Literature
titlestmt.author: by Tom Hyry and Leigh Golden

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday February 7, 2019 at 04:02

did.unittitle: Leon F. Litwack collection of Berkeley, California, protest literature

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of newspapers, periodicals, flyers, handbills, newsletters, mailings, memoranda, reports, sound recordings, and other materials compiled by Leon Litwack that primarily document the protest movements of the 1960s and 1970s, particularly in and around Berkeley, California. The collection includes materials related to civil rights, Vietnam War protests, the Black Panther Party, the Free Speech Movement and the counterculture of the 1960s and 1970s. Also included are memoranda, meeting minutes, reports, and publications distributed to faculty at the University of California, Berkeley.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Serendipity Books on the Frederick W. and Carrie S. Beinecke Fund for Western Americana, 2008.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Leon F. Litwack Collection of Berkeley, California, Protest Literature is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Leon F. Litwack Collection of Berkeley, California, Protest Literature. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, and competing priorities. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a medium level of processing, which included rehousing all material into acid-free folders and boxes, and organizing material into series. Within Series I. Files, the material remains in the order it was received by the library. The library has not attempted to refine its arrangement. The item level descriptions for materials in Series I were created by Serendipity Books and repurposed for this finding aid. These items have not been verified.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Other printed material received with the collection was removed for separate cataloging and can be accessed by searching Orbis (Yale's Online Catalog).

bioghist.head: Leon F. Litwack
bioghist.p: Leon F. Litwack was born in 1929 in Santa Barbara, California. He received a B.A. (1951) and Ph.D. (1958) from the University of California at Berkeley, where he also served as a professor in the History Department from 1965 to 2007. Litwack's scholarship focused on African-American history and he won the Pulitzer Prize in 1980 for his book, Been in the Storm So Long: The Aftermath of Slavery .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Leon F. Litwack Collection of Berkeley, California, Protest Literature consists of newspapers, periodicals, flyers, handbills, newsletters, mailings, memoranda, reports, sound recordings, and other materials compiled by Leon Litwack that primarily document the protest movements of the 1960s and 1970s, particularly in and around Berkeley, California. The collection includes materials related to civil rights, Vietnam War protests, the Black Panther Party, the Free Speech Movement and the counterculture of the 1960s and 1970s. Also included are memoranda, meeting minutes, reports, and publications distributed to faculty at the University of California, Berkeley.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into four series: I. Files. II. Newspapers. III. Periodicals. IV. Sound Recordings.

did.unittitle: Files

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files and the material within them have been kept in the order in which they were received by the library. The original file folders have been replaced and some of the original "files" now occupy multiple folders.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The alphabetical item list for each file is based on a list prepared by the staff of Serendipity Books in Berkelely, California, which accompanied the collection. Library staff has not verified the contents of each folder against the list, nor does the list reflect the physical order of material within any file. There is no item list for File 13.

Oakland 7 (org). WITH A LITTLE HELP FROM OUR FRIENDS. Flyer on behalf of the Oakland 7. March 17, 1969. The Oakland 7 were anti-war protestors (members of the Campus [UC Berkeley] Stop the Draft Week Committee) arrested on October 17, 1967 at the Oakland, California induction center during Stop the Draft Week protest activities. The defendants were charged on January 28, 1969 by the Oakland Grand Jury with conspiracy to commit misdemeanors.

did.unittitle: Sound Recordings
Phonograph records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes two 12-inch (30-cm) 33 1/3 rpm phonographic records: Free Speech Movement's sounds & songs of the demonstration (Berkeley, CA: Free Speech Movement-Records, 1964) and What Shall They Read? (Berkeley, CA: Pacifica Archive Record Foundation, 1968); and two 7-inch 45 rpm phonographic records: Joy to UC: free speech carols (San Francisco: Cireco Music, 1964) and Where have you been today, James Rector? by Kandeda Montgomery (Richmond, CA: LL Liblor Records, 1969).
